deadlines.description: Last day to drop with a W

professors.name: Amanda Lien
professors.reviews: Amazing Lectures, Gives Great Feedback, Overall an easy professor, Very kind and sweet.

professors.name: Edward Ahrens
professors.reviews: Very sweet and kind professor, very easy class, lets students 2 week extension for students to fix lab mistakes, Lectures are quite boring though.

professors.name: Nahrin Rashid
professors.reviews: Patient, structured, and uses clear examples; fair exams.

professors.name: Vinh Nguyen
professors.reviews: Programmatic, clear alignment between homework and tests; strong rating. (~4.2/5 on 83 ratings, 79% would take again, difficulty ~3.0). Recent 2025 reviews for his Calc 1A praise organized lectures and helpful policies; “tough but fair if you keep up with the homework.” Great middle-ground pick.

professors.name: Doli Bambhania
professors.reviews: Big sample and steady results: 4.1/5, 302 ratings, 66% would take again, difficulty 3.3. Themes: caring, clear explanations, lots of homework, three midterms; tests are doable if you keep up.

professors.name: Jelena Segan
professors.reviews: 5.0/5 on 13 ratings (fewer reviews); stellar comments, but limited sample and not many Calc 1A-specific notes yet.

professors.name: Usha Ganeshlingam
professors.reviews: many cite clarity and structured materials; an easier difficulty profile.

professors.name: Lilit Mazmanyan
professors.reviews: Supportive, lots of practice matching exams; extra credit and quick responses. 1B notes mention cheat sheets/WebAssign; predictable assessments.

professors.name: Jian (Andrew) Yu
professors.reviews: Very clear explanations; 1B reviewers say some sections feel lighter, especially async. A bit lecture-heavy for some; starts fast.

professors.name: Linlin Zhang
professors.reviews: Open-note quizzes, one-page notes on exams; online HW is straightforward. Minor slide mistakes noted; supportive and passable if you keep up.

professors.name: Loraine Moen
professors.reviews: Kind, step-by-step approach. For 1B, HW often ungraded; weekly quizzes from HW; cheat sheet allowed on final—low-stress but structured.

professors.name: Christopher N. Bradley
professors.reviews: Supportive and predictable; extra credit; clear lectures. Exams align with prep. (100% WTA, diff ~2.7)

professors.name: John Jimenez
professors.reviews: Chill and fair; drops lowest quiz/exam; tests track class materials. (75% WTA, diff ~2.9)

professors.name: Jianbo (Paul) Du
professors.reviews: Fair/aligned policies; lecture-heavy; some self-study helpful. (62% WTA, diff ~3.0)

professors.name: Millia Ison
professors.reviews: Heavier homework, test-heavy; mixed outcomes—suits students who want lots of practice. (39% WTA, diff ~3.1)

professors.name: Bijan Sadeghi-Hassanvand
professors.reviews: Lots of HW, lecture-heavy; clarity issues noted by some. (38% WTA, diff ~3.2)

professors.name: Hassan Bourgoub
professors.reviews: Very mixed/low satisfaction; heavier workload; some say tests are easy if you self-teach. (22% WTA, diff ~3.4)

professors.name: Fatemeh Yarahmadi
professors.reviews: Supportive, lighter stress, predictable. Recent 1D notes: easy A vibe for prepared students; caring and clear grading.

professors.name: Vadim von Brzeski
professors.reviews: Approachable, encouraging, fair. Smaller sample but comments point to alignment and supportive feedback.

professors.name: Roderic (Rick) Taylor
professors.reviews: Manageable difficulty; tests similar to HW/practice. Some find pacing/handwriting slow—steady if you keep up.

professors.name: James Mailhot
professors.reviews: Clear explanations but tougher testing/homework; more rigor, less 'chill.' Good if you want a push.

professors.name: Kejian Shi
professors.reviews: Very structured but harsh; heavy workload and test-heavy. Better for self-directed grinders.

professors.name: Lucian Sega
professors.reviews: Engaging, inspirational lectures; supportive vibe; often lower stress. Note: RMP page is for SJSU (external campus), used here as a teaching-signal proxy.

professors.name: Jakob Kotas
professors.reviews: Accessible and caring; recent reviews mention organization/partial-credit frustrations. Note: RMP page is for UW (external campus), used as a proxy.

professors.name: Justin Read
professors.reviews: Supportive, flexible, very chill. ZyBooks-driven course, weekly labs, open-book tests, partial/extra credit, fast replies; exams match study guides. (Sometimes listed as Justine Read.)

professors.name: Doug Case
professors.reviews: Organized and engaging; clear grading, helpful feedback, straightforward Canvas flow. Low stress; tiny sample but consistently strong.

professors.name: Abeer Alameer
professors.reviews: Caring and structured; clear rubrics, participation matters, some proctored exams; supportive and responsive with steady weekly work.

professors.name: May Lin
professors.reviews: Friendly, manageable weekly rhythm (quiz + lab + ZyBooks). Late lab resubmits allowed; exam coding mirrors practice. A couple harsher takes on grading, but overall student-friendly.

professors.name: Al-Hussein
professors.reviews: Understanding with fair tests; passionate. Lots of homework; some note accent/clarity—manageable if you keep up. (Listed as “Al Hussein” on RMP.)

professors.name: Mary Pape
professors.reviews: Mixed experiences: organized but can feel test-heavy/tough grading; proctored finals. Many succeed if they stay on top of labs and rubrics.

professors.name: An Lam
professors.reviews: Too little data to judge confidently: one glowing recent 22A review; another says lectures/recordings were hard to follow.

professors.name: Tuan Nguyen
professors.reviews: Recurrent notes of harsh grading, heavy workload, unclear instructions; occasional positives, but risk is high for most 22A students.

professors.name: Alexandre Stoykov
professors.reviews: No RMP ratings yet for 22A—insufficient data to evaluate.

professors.name: Dan Halabe
professors.reviews: Best overall learning + supportive vibe. Consistent recent 22B reviews: you'll learn a lot via useful projects; weekly HW + biweekly solo projects; very caring/accessible; fair difficulty.

professors.name: Shu-Huar Yeh
professors.reviews: Structured with clear rubrics and extra credit; some open-book tests. Several comments say lectures can meander—plan to practice outside class.

professors.name: Hann So
professors.reviews: Heavier workload with tough grading; frequent notes about organization/clarity and group projects; overall experience trends stressful for many.

professors.name: Mirsaeid Abolghasemi
professors.reviews: Very clear and responsive; extra credit and collaborative projects; many say you learn a lot without surprise exams. (Not all reviews are for 22C, but the style is consistently praised.)

professors.name: Jennifer Parrish
professors.reviews: Structured and supportive with heavier weekly load. For 22C: short, clear videos; two labs/week; group project (even async). Exams align with taught methods; caring and accessible.

professors.name: Ronald Kleinman
professors.reviews: Knowledgeable, generous with extra credit; quizzes pulled from lecture (good alignment). Trade-offs: prefers older C++ style and can be strict; a few find lectures dry.

professors.name: Kamran Eftekhari
professors.reviews: Mixed/volatile experience. Recent posts mention lecture–assignment misalignment, strict grading, stress; some note quick email replies and end-of-term curves. Better if very self-directed.

professors.name: Charles De Vogelaere
professors.reviews: Fair, predictable assessments with lower perceived difficulty. Supportive and caring; clear grading criteria and occasional extra credit. Lectures can feel a bit dry, but quizzes/exams align with practice—manageable if you keep up weekly.

courses.title: Beginning Programming Methodologies in C++
courses.description: Intro to C++ programming: variables and types, input/output, conditionals and loops, functions, arrays/vectors/strings, basic object-oriented concepts, file I/O, debugging and testing. Many sections use ZyBooks or similar platforms.
courses.notes: Typical weekly rhythm: ZyBooks reading, quizzes, and a lab. Policies and exam formats vary by instructor—check your section’s syllabus.

courses.title: Intermediate Programming Methodologies in C++
courses.description: Object-oriented programming with C++: classes/objects, encapsulation, constructors/destructors, operator overloading, inheritance and polymorphism, templates, exceptions, recursion, separate compilation, testing and debugging. Emphasis on style, design, and maintainability.
courses.notes: Expect weekly programming assignments and 1–2 projects depending on instructor. Check your section’s syllabus for IDE, late policy, and exam format.

courses.title: Data Abstraction and Structures
courses.description: Linked lists, stacks, queues, trees, hash tables, graphs, algorithms.

courses.title: Calculus I
courses.description: Limits, derivatives, applications, and intro integrals.
courses.notes: Get familiar with your homework platform.

courses.title: Calculus II
courses.description: You’ll learn techniques of integration (substitution, parts, trig substitution, partial fractions), improper integrals, and applications (areas, volumes, arc length, work). Then dive into sequences & series: convergence tests (comparison, ratio, root, integral, alternating), power/Taylor–Maclaurin series with radius/interval of convergence. Many sections also touch parametric & polar curves.
courses.notes: Check your section’s syllabus—policies vary by instructor.

courses.title: Calculus III
courses.description: Sequences and series, parametric and polar, applications of integration (topics vary by catalog).
courses.notes: Check your section’s syllabus—policies vary by instructor.

courses.title: Calculus IV (Multivariable & Vector Calculus)
courses.description: Vectors and geometry in 3D; partial derivatives and gradients; multiple integrals; vector fields; line and surface integrals; Green’s, Stokes’, and Divergence theorems (topics may vary by catalog/section).
courses.notes: Check your section’s syllabus—policies vary by instructor.

courses.title: Differential Equations
courses.description: First-order DEs (separable, linear, exact), higher-order linear DEs with constant coefficients, particular solutions (method of undetermined coefficients/variation of parameters), Laplace transforms, systems of DEs, qualitative phase-plane ideas, and applications. Some sections include series solutions or numerical methods.
courses.notes: Policies vary by instructor; check your section’s syllabus.

courses.title: Linear Algebra
courses.description: Systems of linear equations and Gaussian elimination; matrices and matrix algebra; vector spaces and subspaces; linear independence, basis, dimension; linear transformations and change of basis; determinants; eigenvalues/eigenvectors and diagonalization; orthogonality and least squares; applications.
courses.notes: Exact topics/pace vary by instructor—check your section’s syllabus.

CIS 22A.name: Justin Read
CIS 22A.notes: ZyBooks-driven, open-book tests, partial/extra credit, fast replies; exams match guides. 4.5/5, 88% WTA, diff 2.6 (8 ratings).

CIS 22A.name: Doug Case
CIS 22A.notes: Clear grading, helpful feedback, straightforward Canvas flow; fair exams. 4.8/5, 100% WTA, diff 2.2 (5 ratings).

CIS 22A.name: Abeer Alameer
CIS 22A.notes: Clear rubrics, participation matters; supportive with steady weekly work. 4.1/5, 77% WTA, diff 3.2 (97 ratings).

CIS 22A.name: May Lin
CIS 22A.notes: Weekly quiz+lab+ZyBooks; late resubmits; exams mirror practice. 4.1/5, 78% WTA, diff 2.9 (9 ratings).

CIS 22A.name: Al-Hussein
CIS 22A.notes: Passionate and fair; accent/clarity noted by some. 3.7/5, 71% WTA, diff 2.0 (27 ratings).

CIS 22A.name: Mary Pape
CIS 22A.notes: Can feel tough/proctored; success if you track labs/rubrics. 3.3/5, 54% WTA, diff 2.7 (131 ratings).

CIS 22A.name: An Lam
CIS 22A.notes: One recent strong 22A review, one critical about clarity; too little data. 3.0/5, 50% WTA, diff 2.5 (2 ratings).

CIS 22A.name: Tuan Nguyen
CIS 22A.notes: Risky pick for most beginners. 1.4/5, 13% WTA, diff 4.0 (34 ratings).

CIS 22A.name: Alexandre Stoykov
CIS 22A.notes: No RMP ratings yet—kept last purely as a placeholder until data appears.

CIS 22B.name: Dan Halabe
CIS 22B.notes: You’ll learn a lot; caring/accessible; weekly HW + biweekly solo projects; fair difficulty. RMP: 5.0/5, 100% WTA, diff 2.4 (23 ratings).

CIS 22B.name: Edward Ahrens
CIS 22B.notes: Very lenient and kind; resubmissions common; recorded lectures. Trade-off: some say you may need extra self-study for depth. RMP: 3.8/5, 79% WTA, diff 1.7 (90 ratings).

CIS 22B.name: Shu-Huar Yeh
CIS 22B.notes: Clear rubrics and EC; some open-book tests; several reviews say lectures meander—practice outside class. RMP: 3.4/5, 67% WTA, diff 2.8 (35 ratings).

CIS 22B.name: Hann So
CIS 22B.notes: Lots of HW and group work; clarity/organization concerns. Overall more stressful for many. RMP: 2.1/5, 41% WTA, diff 3.4 (74 ratings).

CIS 22C.name: Mirsaeid Abolghasemi
CIS 22C.notes: Most consistent, student-first. Very clear, responsive; EC and collaborative projects; lots learned without surprise exams. 4.7/5, 92% WTA, diff 2.8 (223 ratings).

CIS 22C.name: Jennifer Parrish
CIS 22C.notes: Structured, supportive, heavier weekly load. For 22C: short/clear videos, two labs/week, group project; exams align with taught methods; caring and accessible. 4.3/5, 81% WTA, diff 2.9 (111).

CIS 22C.name: Al-Hussein
CIS 22C.notes: Fair policies and manageable difficulty. Lectures can be a bit hard to follow at times, but tests/HW are fair with clear grading and reasonable extensions. 3.7/5, 71% WTA, diff 2.0 (27).

CIS 22C.name: Ronald Kleinman
CIS 22C.notes: Knowledgeable; generous EC; quizzes from lecture (good alignment). Prefers older C++ style; can be strict; some find lectures dry. 3.7/5, 64% WTA, diff 3.3 (32).

CIS 22C.name: Kamran Eftekhari
CIS 22C.notes: Mixed/volatile. Reports of misalignment, strict grading, and stress; some quick replies and curves. Riskier unless very self-directed. 3.2/5, 43% WTA, diff 3.0 (117).

MATH 1A.name: Jelena Segan
MATH 1A.notes: Stellar reviews but review sample is very small. Professor looks very promising though.

MATH 1A.name: Doli Bambhania
MATH 1A.notes: Lots of homework but explains concepts really well. Really caring for students.

MATH 1A.name: Usha Ganeshlingam
MATH 1A.notes: Recent reviews are mixed but overall a solid class.

MATH 1B.name: Nahrin Rashid
MATH 1B.notes: Care + structure; online quizzes/tests (2 attempts) and unlimited HW attempts cited by 1B students; keeps a tough class doable.

MATH 1B.name: Lilit Mazmanyan
MATH 1B.notes: Supportive, predictable assessments; cheat sheets/WebAssign; extra credit and fast replies.

MATH 1B.name: Charles De Vogelaere
MATH 1B.notes: Lower perceived difficulty; fair, predictable assessments; manageable workload if you keep up with weekly practice.

MATH 1B.name: Jian (Andrew) Yu
MATH 1B.notes: Very clear explanations; some formats perceived as lighter (esp. async); can be lecture-heavy/fast early on.

MATH 1B.name: Linlin Zhang
MATH 1B.notes: Open-note quizzes; one-page notes on exams; straightforward online HW; supportive and organized.

MATH 1B.name: Loraine Moen
MATH 1B.notes: Kind, step-by-step; HW often ungraded; weekly quizzes from HW; cheat sheet for cumulative final.

MATH 1C.name: Christopher N. Bradley
MATH 1C.notes: Supportive + predictable; exams align with prep; small but very positive sample.

MATH 1C.name: John Jimenez
MATH 1C.notes: Drops lowest quiz/exam; tests track class notes; friendly/fair.

MATH 1C.name: Linlin Zhang
MATH 1C.notes: Open-note quizzes; one-page notes allowed; ‘do the work and you’re fine.’

MATH 1C.name: Loraine Moen
MATH 1C.notes: Weekly quizzes often from HW; cheat-sheet final in some sections; very caring.

MATH 1C.name: Jianbo (Paul) Du
MATH 1C.notes: Clear criteria; a bit lecture-heavy; fine if you can self-study some.

MATH 1C.name: Millia Ison
MATH 1C.notes: Lots of practice and time commitment; mixed outcomes.

MATH 1C.name: Bijan Sadeghi-Hassanvand
MATH 1C.notes: Lecture-heavy; clarity issues noted by some students.

MATH 1C.name: Hassan Bourgoub
MATH 1C.notes: Mixed/low satisfaction overall; some succeed if self-teaching.

MATH 1C.name: Lucian Sega
MATH 1C.notes: Strong RMP is for SJSU (not De Anza)—include for style context only.

MATH 1D.name: Fatemeh Yarahmadi
MATH 1D.notes: Supportive and student-friendly; clear grading; recent 1D posts mention 'nice and easy A' vibe if you keep up.

MATH 1D.name: Vadim von Brzeski
MATH 1D.notes: Approachable, caring, good feedback; smaller sample but consistent alignment comments.

MATH 1D.name: Roderic (Rick) Taylor
MATH 1D.notes: Tests similar to HW/practice; pacing/handwriting can be slow for some.

MATH 1D.name: James Mailhot
MATH 1D.notes: Clear lectures; heavier homework and tougher testing—good for students seeking rigor.

MATH 1D.name: Kejian Shi
MATH 1D.notes: Structured but harsh; lots of homework and test focus.

MATH 1D.name: Hassan Bourgoub
MATH 1D.notes: Some say tests can be easy if you self-teach; many report unclear structure/grading.

MATH 2A.name: Roderic (Rick) Taylor
MATH 2A.notes: Helpful and patient; assessments predictable and aligned with practice; lower stress if you keep up. Stats: 3.3/5 overall, 56% WTA, diff 2.9, 186 ratings.

MATH 2A.name: Kejian Shi
MATH 2A.notes: Very structured with clear criteria; heavy workload and tougher grading; prep pays off if disciplined. Stats: 2.6/5 overall, 28% WTA, diff 3.6, 469 ratings.

MATH 2A.name: Hassan Bourgoub
MATH 2A.notes: Reports of unclear organization outweigh easier quizzes/exams for many; overall experience trends stressful. Stats: 2.2/5 overall, 22% WTA, diff 3.4, 436 ratings.

MATH 2B.name: Lucian Sega
MATH 2B.notes: Inspirational and engaging; supportive vibe; difficulty not punishing for many. Caveat: RMP page is for SJSU (not DA). RMP: 4.9/5 overall, 100% WTA, diff 2.6, 20 ratings.

MATH 2B.name: James Mailhot
MATH 2B.notes: Clear lecturer but stricter grading and test-heavy; good if you want rigor and can keep a steady rhythm. RMP (DA): 3.6/5 overall, 44% WTA, diff 3.2, 156 ratings.

MATH 2B.name: Jakob Kotas
MATH 2B.notes: Often praised as caring/accessible; some concerns about organization/partial credit. RMP page is for UW (not DA). RMP (UW): 3.5/5 overall, 66% WTA, diff 3.4, 25 ratings.

faq.q: Where do I find the academic calendar?
faq.a: Check the Registrar/Academic Calendar page on your college website.

faq.q: How many units are considered full-time?
faq.a: 12+ units is considered full time at De Anza.

faq.q: Is there free tutoring on campus?
faq.a: Yes—visit the tutoring center page for drop-in hours and subjects.

upper_division: Math 54 Linear Algebra and Differential Equations
Data C8 - Foundations of Data Science
COMPSCI 61A - The Structure and Interpretation of Computer Programs
majors.notes: Domain Emphasis varies (e.g., Business, Cognition, Geo, Health). Use ASSIST for articulation from CC to UCB. https://assist.org/transfer/results?year=75&institution=113&agreement=79&agreementType=to&viewAgreementsOptions=true&view=agreement&viewBy=major&viewSendingAgreements=false&viewByKey=75%2F113%2Fto%2F79%2FMajor%2F648bdbf3-f87d-4a4e-7e0b-08dcb87d5deb

UCLA’s primary DS-aligned major is Data Theory (Math+Stats); many students also combine CS+Stats. USE Assist to clarify: https://assist.org/transfer/results?year=75&institution=113&agreement=117&agreementType=to&viewAgreementsOptions=true&view=agreement&viewBy=major&viewSendingAgreements=false&viewByKey=75%2F113%2Fto%2F117%2FMajor%2Fdf83159c-6975-4ca5-cc1b-08dc9134ea85

Lowkey some of the dumbest major requirements I have ever seen. Use assist.org to clarify: https://assist.org/transfer/results?year=75&institution=113&agreement=7&agreementType=to&viewAgreementsOptions=true&view=agreement&viewBy=major&viewSendingAgreements=false&viewByKey=75%2F113%2Fto%2F7%2FMajor%2Fda31dba3-8138-4ece-a822-08dca807bc76

lower_division: CIS 5 OR CIS 22A OR CIS 35A OR CIS 40 OR CIS 41A
CIS 22B OR CIS 22BH OR CIS 26A OR CIS 26B OR CIS 26BH
majors.notes: UCSB has either a B.A. or B.S. choice for Data Science. Use Assist.org to clarify: https://assist.org/transfer/results?year=75&institution=113&agreement=128&agreementType=to&viewAgreementsOptions=true&view=agreement&viewBy=major&viewSendingAgreements=false&viewByKey=75%2F113%2Fto%2F128%2FMajor%2Feda5a4d4-8165-478a-97fe-08dcd6abdbb0

Program usually offered via ICS (Informatics/CS). Check catalog year; course codes may change. lower_division: MATH 10 OR MATH 17 OR PSYC 15 OR SOC 15
majors.notes: UCD provides domain tracks; verify with latest catalog and ASSIST for CC articulation: https://assist.org/transfer/results?year=75&institution=113&agreement=89&agreementType=to&viewAgreementsOptions=true&view=agreement&viewBy=major&viewSendingAgreements=false&viewByKey=75%2F113%2Fto%2F89%2FMajor%2Fe2aafd38-f1e3-4e7a-137a-08dcbcdb53de

There is no specific Data Science major for UCSC. Use Assist to verify: https://assist.org/transfer/results?year=75&institution=113&agreement=132&agreementType=to&viewAgreementsOptions=true&view=agreement&viewBy=major&viewSendingAgreements=false&viewByKey=75%2F113%2Fto%2F132%2FMajor%2F0423047a-8a1d-4d0a-b495-08dca4e7496b

CIS 22B OR CIS 27 OR CIS 28 OR CIS 29 OR (CIS 36A AND CIS 36B)
majors.notes: Course prefixes may be in CS, STAT, or EE; confirm catalog year. USE ASSIST TO VERIFY: https://assist.org/transfer/results?year=75&institution=113&agreement=46&agreementType=to&viewAgreementsOptions=true&view=agreement&viewBy=major&viewSendingAgreements=false&viewByKey=75%2F113%2Fto%2F46%2FMajor%2F6cd925f5-096e-4c87-a195-08dcf4773cca

majors.notes: UCM is expanding DS offerings; always confirm with the current catalog.
